page.title: 08St.Peters Church,Ropley.
page.content: In the Domesday survey of 1085 the church in Ropley was part of the Hundred of Esselei.The only Norman feature to be seen now is the door in the south transept.The church has been extended from these early times up to the end of the 19th century.The bell tower was built at the end of the 14th century with a ring of 4 bells which was increased to 5 in 1701 and to 6 in 1927 when a treble was added.The font is from the 15th century.The Church registers date from 1538 the year in which Thomas Cromwell ordered them to be kept.The church is dedicated to St. Peter and is now the main church in the combined parishes of Ropley,West Tisted and Bishops Sutton.The Monkwood Mission is also part of the parish. The present vicar is the Rev.A.m.c. Dunn who lives with his family in the Vicarage in Lyeway Lane.
